docs.lead_paragraph: Senator John Kerry's support for abortion rights and stem cell research has prompted discussions among Roman Catholic bishops and Vatican officials over how to respond to a presidential candidate who professes Catholicism while taking stands contrary to church teaching. The issue has been a topic in the Vatican this week as bishops from Florida, Georgia and North and South Carolina hold long-scheduled meetings with the pope and Vatican officials on a variety of issues.

headline.main: Kerry, Candidate and Catholic, Creates Uneasiness for Church

docs.abstract: America's Roman Catholic bishops and Vatican officials consider how to respond to presidential candidate John Kerry, Catholic who takes stands contrary to church teaching on abortion and stem cell research; bishops are troubled by Kerry's recent vote against bill that makes it crime to harm fetus during assault on pregnant woman; bishops are unlikely to make overt endorsements, and consistently say they favor neither Democrats nor Republicans; but it could have impact on some Catholic voters if some influential prelates choose to publicly embrace Kerry or to snub him; Catholics make up 27 percent of electorate and belong to largest church in country; many live in states with large blocs of electoral votes; exit polls in states that have already held their Democratic primaries show Kery did very well among Catholics; Bishop John H Ricard is chairman of task force expected to produce guidelines for American bishops on relations with Catholic politicians; photo (M)
docs.snippet: Senator John Kerry's support for abortion rights and stem cell research has prompted discussions among Roman Catholic bishops and Vatican officials over how to respond to a presidential candidate who professes Catholicism while taking stands contrary...

byline.original: By LAURIE GOODSTEIN; Jason Horowitz contributed reporting from Rome for this article

headline.main: Bush Signs New Law on Harming of Fetuses

docs.abstract: Photo of Pres Bush signing bill make it a crime to harm fetus during commission of federal crime; those present include mother and stepfather of Laci Peterson, pregnant woman murdered in California last year
docs.snippet: Photo of Pres Bush signing bill make it a crime to harm fetus during commission of federal crime; those present include mother and stepfather of Laci Peterson, pregnant woman murdered in California last year

docs.lead_paragraph: A mother whose unborn child dies because of a doctor's negligence can now sue for the emotional distress she suffers, New York's highest court ruled on Thursday, reversing a precedent it set two decades ago. The decision by the New York Court of Appeals opens the door to increased litigation that the already besieged medical community said could further undermine doctors' ability to work.

headline.main: Albany Court Reverses Rule On Stillbirths

docs.abstract: New York State Court of Appeals rules that mother whose unborn child dies because of doctor's negligence can now sue for emotional distress she suffers; decision reverses 20-year-old precedent that mother and fetus are separate entities; could affect national debate on abortion and rights of unborn; obstetricians and gynecologists fear decison opens door to increased litigation (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: An article on Saturday about laws criminalizing harm to a fetus referred incorrectly to a 1990 case in which an appeals court said court decisions compelling women to undergo Caesarean sections were expected to be extremely rare. It was a civil case, not criminal.
docs.abstract: Correction of Mar 27 article on laws criminalizing harm to fetus; 1990 case cited was civil case, not criminal
